Feature: Are there definite or specific articles?
Do indefinite nominals commonly have indefinite articles?
Are there prenominal articles?
Are there postnominal articles?
What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?
Example: viźɘ šurt [three house] ‘three houses’

Feature: What is the order of adnominal demonstrative and noun?
Example: vəʷl śin [that person] ‘that man’

Feature: Can adnominal property words occur discontinuously?
Are nominal conjunction and comitative expressed by different elements?
Example:
kaɣal-ba puyan
[lazybones-INST rich.man]
‘The Lazybones and the Rich Man’
man-ba pɘrle kilǰɘ
[1SG-INST together.with come]
‘He came together with me.’

Feature: Is there an inclusive/exclusive distinction?
Is there a gender distinction in independent 3rd person pronouns?
Is there a dual or unit augmented form (in addition to plural or augmented) for all person categories in the pronoun system?
Are there three or more distance contrasts in demonstratives?
Detailed comment: three-way contrast: ku ‘this’, leS@ ‘that’, sak@ ‘this here’ (emphasized), sav@ ‘that over there’ (2nd level, more distant, mentioned before), v@l ‘that, the afore mentioned’ (3rd level, most distant from the speaker)
Example:
ku, śakə ‘this’
śavə ‘that’ (medial)
leš ‘that over there’, distal

Feature: Do demonstratives show an elevation distinction?
Do demonstratives show a visible-nonvisible distinction?
Are there demonstrative classifiers?
Is there nonphonological allomorphy of noun number markers?
Are there several nouns (more than three) which are suppletive for number?
Is there productive overt morphological singular marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological dual marking on nouns?
Is there productive morphological plural marking on nouns?
Example: xur@n-sem [birch-PL], pyrt-sem [house-PL], hut-sem [paper-PL]

Feature: Is there an associative plural marker for nouns?
Example:
ivanov-zem [Ivanov-PL] ‘members of the Ivanov’s family’
kaɣal-zem [lazy-PL] ‘the lazybones and his family’

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an action/state noun from a verb?
Example:
sut- ‘to sell’ > sut@ ‘sale’
kaš- ‘to transport, to cross’ > kaš@ ‘transport, crossing’
p@t- ‘to go to an end’ > p@tm@š ‘finish, end’
v@s- ‘to fly’ > v@sev ‘flight’
jurat- ‘to love’ > juratu ‘love’
kil- ‘to come’ > kily ‘arrival’

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an agent noun from a verb?
Comment: According to Savelev (p.c. 2017), the suffix is not productive.
Example:
p@x- ‘to watch’ > p@xa ‘warden’
j@pat- ‘to console’ > j@patm@S ‘consoler’
l@rka- ‘to grumble’ > l@rkam@S ‘grumbler’

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an object noun from a verb?
Example: vit- ‘to cover with a roof’ > vite ‘cowshed’

Feature: Is there a noun class/gender system where sex is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where shape is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where animacy is a factor in class assignment?
Is there a noun class/gender system where plant status is a factor in class assignment?
Are there numeral classifiers?
Are there possessive classifiers?
Is the adnominal possessive construction different for alienable and inalienable nouns?
Detailed comment:
alienable: possessive pronoun
inalienable: optional possessive pronoun + possessive suffix on the possessed
Example:
san sědel-e
[2SG.POSS table-ACC]
‘your table’
(san) all-u-na
[(2SG.POSS) hand-2SG.POSS-ACC]
‘your hand’

Feature: What is the pragmatically unmarked order of adnominal possessor noun and possessed noun?
Example:
їvəl-u [son-2SG] ‘your son’, xɘr-y [daughter-2SG] ‘your daughter’, sɘdel-Em [table-1SG] ‘my table’, sɘdel-y [table-2SG] ‘your table’, ur-i [leg-3SG] ‘his leg’
san sědel-e [2SG.POSS table-ACC] ‘your table’

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like verbs in predicative position?
Example:
šurə śəʷmarda [white egg] ‘a white egg’
śəʷmarda šurə [egg white] ‘the egg is white’
śăмарта šurăččĕ ‘the egg was white’

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as verbs?
Are there morphological cases for non-pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Example:
ku kěneke-ne vulat
[DEM book-OBJ read]
‘He is reading the book.’

Feature: Are there morphological cases for pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Are there morphological cases for oblique non-pronominal NPs (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Detailed comment:
locative -ta/-če
ablative -ran/-ren/-tan/-ten
instrumental-comitative -pa/-pe
abessiv -s@r
causal-final -s@n
orientative -a/-e/-na/-ne + -lla/-lle
imstrumental -in/-n
Example:
tul-ta [yard-LOC] ‘in the yard’
arman-sen-čen [windmill-PL-ABL] ‘from the windmills’
pulǎ šiv-ra išet
[fish water-LOC swim]
‘The fish swims in the water.’

Feature: Are there morphological cases for oblique independent personal pronouns (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Detailed comment:
1SG
LOC man-ra
ABL man-rav
INST man-pa
ABESS man-sar
CAUS/FIN man-San

Feature: Are there prepositions?
Are there postpositions?
Do verbs have prefixes/proclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Do verbs have suffixes/enclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Is there productive infixation in verbs?

yurla-d-əp
[sing-PRS-1SG]

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to past tense?
Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to future tense?
Is a morphological distinction between perfective and imperfective aspect available on verbs?
Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Detailed comment:
person markers for PRS: 1SG -p, 2SG -n, 3SG/PL -@, 1PL -pVr, 2PL -r
person markers for PST: 1SG -m, 2SG -n, 3SG/PL -@, 1PL -mVr, 2PL -r
Example:
kay-əb-ər [go-1-PL] ‘we will go’
kay-ər [go-2PL] ‘you will go’
1SG pїradə-p [go-1SG]
2SG pїradə-n [go-2SG]
3SG pїrat’ [go]
1PL pїrat-pər [go-1PL]
2PL pїradə-r [go-2PL]
3PL pїra-śś-ɘ [go-PL-3PL]

Feature: Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Detailed comment:
person markers for PRS: 1SG -p, 2SG -n, 3SG/PL -@, 1PL -pVr, 2PL -r
person markers for PST: 1SG -m, 2SG -n, 3SG/PL -@, 1PL -mVr, 2PL -r

Feature: Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Detailed comment:
ku kěneke-ne vulat
[DEM book-OBJ read]
‘He is reading the book.’

Feature: Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on TAM distinctions?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on verb classes?
Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on person distinctions?
Can verb stems alter according to the person of a core participant?
Is there a benefactive applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Is there an instrumental applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Can the recipient in a ditransitive construction be marked like the monotransitive patient?
Example:
ku kěneke-ne vulat
[DEM book-OBJ read]
‘He is reading the book.’

Feature: Can standard negation be marked by an affix, clitic or modification of the verb?
Detailed comment:
suffix -mas/-mes for durative present,
-mǎ/-mě for other cases
Example:
tupay-mas-tǎr 
[find-NEG.DUR.PRS-2PL]
‘You cannot find.’

Feature: Is there directional or locative morphological marking on verbs?
Is there verb suppletion for participant number?
Is there verb suppletion for tense or aspect?
Are there conjugation classes?
Detailed comment: 10 verbs ending in -r and losing it in conjugation

Feature: Are there verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones?
Is there a phonologically bound reflexive marker on the verb?
Example: śəʷv-əʷn [wash-REFL] ‘wash oneself’

Feature: Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?
Example: kala-ś [talk-RECIP] ‘to talk to each other’

Feature: Do verbs classify the shape, size or consistency of absolutive arguments by means of incorporated nouns, verbal affixes or suppletive verb stems?

Are there serial verb constructions?
Can mood be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Can aspect be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Can tense be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Is verb compounding a regular process?
Are there verb-adjunct (aka light-verb) constructions?
Is incorporation of nouns into verbs a productive intransitivizing process?
Is there an existential verb?
Are different posture verbs used obligatorily depending on an inanimate locatum's shape or position (e.g. 'to lie' vs. 'to stand')?
Is there a notably small number, i.e. about 100 or less, of verb roots in the language?

Example:
škula kayadəp
[school go.1SG]

pulə šїv-ra išet
[fish water-LOC swim]

Feature: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-initial for transitive clauses?
Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-medial for transitive clauses?

Example:
čul šїvra pudat’ mɘnžɘn tesen vəʷl š1vran j1vər
[stone water.LOC sink.PRS.3SG what.CAUS/FIN say.PTCP 3SG water.ABL heavy]
‘The stone does not sink in the water, because it is heavier than water.’

Feature: Do clausal objects usually occur in the same position as nominal objects?
Example:
epe vəʷl  əśtine pɘlmestɘp
1SG 3SG where.NOM.DAT/ACC know.NEG.PRS.1SG
‘I do not know where he is.’

Example:
kěneke ilt@m [book buy.PST] ‘I bought a book.’
škula kajat@p [school go.1SG] ‘I go to school.’

Example: tupay-mas-tǎr [find-NEG.DUR.PRS-2PL] ‘You cannot find.’

Feature: Can standard negation be marked clause-initially?
Is there a difference between imperative (prohibitive) and declarative negation constructions?
Example:
s1r-m-@p [write-NEG-1SG] ‘I will not write.’
an il [NEG take] ‘Don’t take (SG)!’
an il-@r [NEG take-3PL] ‘Don’t take (PL)!'

Feature: Is verbal predication marked by the same negator as all of the following types of predication: locational, existential and nominal?

śurǎ śǎmarta [white egg] ‘a white egg’

-i
it attaches to the last element in the clause

Juan window-DAT/ACC break-PRET

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessed noun?
Comment: Possessor is marked on the possessed.

1SG
NOM Ele
DAT/ACC man-a

[read-CONV sit]

Feature: Are specific non-finite and finite suffixes expressed by a formally identical suffix?
Are specific negative verbs and negative suffixes/particles expressed by a formally identical suffix?
Detailed comment:
an - preposed to the verb, vowel harmony does not apply to it
the verb i- < e- < er- ‘to be’ has not been preserved in Chuvash, only in the suffix -čtS@ < 3SG/PL.PST *eti > *it@ > č@ and in the NEG *emär > imär > mer~mar; mar/mer ~ turc. emes < *ermäz

Feature: Can 1PL marker be augmented by a collective plural marker?
Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like nouns in predicative position?
Example:
tErEs s@max ‘a truthful word’, tErEs kala- ‘to tell the truth’, tErEse jurat- ‘to like the truth’
śǎmarta Surri [egg white] ‘the egg is white’

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as nouns?
Example: śurǎ śǎmarta [white egg] ‘a white egg’

Feature: Is there a non-initial velar nasal?
Is there a reciprocal marker that is distinct from the reflexive marker?
Detailed comment: verbal marking is identical, but there are free-standing reflexive markers

Example:
vǎl šiv ǎs-ma annǎ
[he water draw-INF went.down]

lart- ‘to set, place’

Feature: Is there a male/female distinction in the sibling terms from the perspective of the speaker?
Is there an age distinction in sibling terms?
Example: pičče ‘elder brother’

Feature: Are nouns most commonly derived from verbs than the other way around?
Are ‘hand’ and ‘arm’ expressed by the same term?
Example:
alǎ ‘hand’
ura ‘foot’
ura ‘leg’

Feature: Are ‘moon’ and ‘month’ expressed by the same term?
Example:

Feature: Is there a plural/collective suffix that is restricted to animates?

Are demonstratives verbally encoded?
Do cardinal numerals require agreement on noun phrases?
Example: širěm sětel [twenty table] ‘twenty tables’

Feature: Is nominative case unmarked?
Example:
pulǎ šiv-ra išet
[fish water-LOC swim]
‘The fish swims in the water.’

Feature: Are accusative-marked objects specific while unmarked objects are non-specific?
Example:
kěneke vulat
[book read]
‘He reads books/a book.’
ku kěneke-ne vulat
[DEM book-OBJ read]
‘He is reading the book.’

Feature: Are recipient and location expressed by the same marker?
Detailed comment:
object relational suffix: -e/-ye/-a/-na/-ne
can mark beneficiary, patient, direction
apart from this suffix, there are other locational suffixes
Example:
uy-e [field-OBJ] ‘to the field’
šǎši-ye [mouse-OBJ] ‘to a mouse’
epir irpe šupaškara šitrěměr ‘We came to Cheboksary in the morning.'

Feature: Is there a distinction between marking of interrogation in polar and content questions?
Example:
payan měn kun
[today what day]
‘What day is today?’
esir miSe śulta
[2SG how.many year]
‘How old are you?’
esir śirěm śičtSěre-i
[2SG 20 7-Q]
‘Are you 27?’

Feature: Is acting agent in passive clause expressed by a dative-marked noun phrase?
Is the subject of an adnominalized clause marked by the genitive case?
Example:
esir yula-kan yurǎ
[you sing-PRS.PTCP song]
‘the song which you are singing’

Feature: Can a passive construction have adversative meaning?
Can demonstrative/interrogative verbs be derived from pronouns and light verbs ‘to do’?
Are causative and passive expressed by a formally identical marker?
Are converb suffixes and deverbal noun suffixes formally identical?
Detailed comment:
deverbal nouns: suffix -a/-e, -m@S, -a/-e, -@, -m@S, -u/-y, -v
coverbs: -a/-e ‘action completely subordinated to the main action […] translated into English by a form in -ing’
-sa/-se ‘coordinate converb’
-san/-sen ‘past gerund’
-iččen ‘antecedent converb’
Example:
deverbal nouns:
vit- ‘to cover with a roof’ > vite ‘cowshed’
sut- ‘to sell’ > sut@ ‘sale’
kaš- ‘to transport, to cross’ > kaš@ ‘transport, crossing’
p@t- ‘to go to an end’ > p@tm@š ‘finish, end’
v@s- ‘to fly’ > v@sev ‘flight’
jurat- ‘to love’ > juratu ‘love’
kil- ‘to come’ > kily ‘arrival’
starik vara pit χuyχǎr-a puślanǎ 
[old.man since ?? cry-CONV begin.PST]
‘the old man began crying greatly.’

Feature: Are quotative markers adverbial derivations from a verb ‘to say’?
Can relational adpositions (e.g. ‘under’) be derived from a place noun (e.g. ‘bottom’) and a locational suffix (e.g. at LOC)?
Detailed comment:
ayak ‘side’
Ci ‘surface’
um ‘front’ 
varǎ ‘midst
tǎrǎ ‘upon’
χěr ‘edge’
Cum ‘along’
pat ‘direction, towards’
ǎSě ‘interior, inside’
Example:
kěneke ay-ne tetrad’ χur
[book underside-OBJ notebook put]
‘Put the notebook under the book.’
kěneke śi-ne tetrad’ χur
[book surface-OBJ notebook put]
‘Put the notebook on the book.’
